idCitation.otherCitDet: Data Citation: Kazmierczak, A. Cavan, G. Connelly, A. and Lindley, S. (2015). Mapping Flood Disadvantage in Scotland 2015. The Scottish Government, Edinburgh, UK.

cntAddress.delPoint: School of Planning and Geography, Cardiff University, Glamorgan Building, King Edward VII Avenue
School of Science & the Environment, Manchester Metropolitan University, John Dalton Building, Chester Street

dataExt.exDesc: This dataset covers the entire administrative area of Scotland.

dataIdInfo.idPurp:
This dataset is the final output of the 'Mapping Flood Disadvantage in Scotland 2015' project commissioned by The Scottish Government in January 2015. The aim of this research was to provide up-to-date spatial assessment of social vulnerability to flooding and flood disadvantage in Scotland, to enable local authorities, service providers and other agencies to better target work around flood resilience and response, and in particular to assist local authorities in meeting their duties under the Flood Risk Management (Scotland) Act 2009.
The research was conducted by Dr Aleksandra Kazmierczak (Cardiff University), Dr Gina Cavan (Manchester Metropolitan University), Dr Angela Connelly (University of Manchester) and Dr Sarah Lindley (University of Manchester).
dataIdInfo.idCredit: The data should be acknowledged or referenced as follows: Kazmierczak, A. Cavan, G. Connelly, A. and Lindley, S. (2015). Mapping Flood Disadvantage in Scotland 2015. The Scottish Government, Edinburgh, UK.
dataIdInfo.idAbs:
Flood disadvantage is presented for the whole of Scotland at Data Zone level(for 6500 Data Zones in total). In addition, the dataset contains:

  • 34 vulnerability indicators (as percentage and standardised values)

  • Social vulnerability to flooding (standardised index and dimensions of vulnerability)

  • Percentage of households exposed to flooding - provided for any type of flooding (coastal, river, surface water combined) and for different return periods (1 in 10; 1 in 25/30; 1 in 200; and 1 in 200 years including the impacts of climate change

  • Flood disadvantage (standardised index for different types of flooding and varying return periods)

  • Geographical location (rurality, coastal and inland areas are classified)

A detailed methodology document is available. Please contact the data owners if this is not supplied with the dataset.

searchKeys.keyword: Flooding; Social Vulnerability; Climate Change; Scotland; Data Zone; Disadvantage

themeKeys.keyword: Flooding; Social vulnerability; Disadvantage; Scotland; Data Zone; Climate Change

LegConsts.othConsts: The dataset contains Data Zone boundaries 2001 from Ordnance Survey. Available under the Ordnance Survey (OS) Open Data Licence (www.ordnancesurvey.co.uk/opendata/licence)

The dataset contains information from the Scottish Census 2011 available from the National Records of Scotland (http://www.scotlandscensus.gov.uk).This information is licensed under the terms of the Open Government Licence [http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/doc/open-government-licence/version/2].

The dataset contains information from the Scottish Census 2001 from the General Register Office for Scotland. This information is licensed under the terms of the Open Government Licence [http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/doc/open-government-licence/version/2].

The dataset contains information from the Scottish Government (SG) Urban Rural Classification, Copyright Scottish Government, contains Ordnance Survey data © Crown copyright and database right (2015). This information is licensed under the terms of the Open Government Licence [http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/doc/open-government-licence/version/2].

dataLineage.statement:
This dataset contains the results of the Mapping Flood Disadvantage in Scotland 2015 project. The GIS dataset contains the following information (see the Fields metadata for a specific description of each field): 1. Vulnerability indicators. The 34 indicators that were used to calculate the index of social vulnerability to flooding are provided. In order to calculate the index of social vulnerability to flooding, the indicators were standardised, weighted and combined together. The standardised values are also provided. 2. Social vulnerability to flooding. The standardised index of social vulnerability is provided, together with the values of the dimensions of vulnerability - sensitivity, ability to prepare for, respond to and recover after flooding. For the social vulnerability to flooding index and its dimensions, 0 is the national average; positive values indicate above-average vulnerability, sensitivity, enhanced exposure and inability to prepare for, respond to and recover after flooding; and negative values mean below-average levels of vulnerability, sensitivity, enhanced exposure and inability to prepare for, respond to and recover after flooding. The classification of the values of the indices into <string> categories is also provided. 3. Percentage of households exposed to flooding. The percentage of residential properties exposed to flooding , i.e. the percentage of households in the data zone that are located within flood maps representing the extent of different flood types (coastal, river, surface water) is provided for any type of flooding and for different return periods (1 in 10; 1 in 25/30; 1 in 200; and 1 in 200 years including the impacts of climate change). 4. Flood disadvantage. The level of flood disadvantage (i.e. the combination of social vulnerability to flooding and the percentage of households exposed to flooding) for data zones is provided. This includes the values of the standardised flood disadvantage index for different types of flooding and varying return periods, where 0 is national average, positive values indicate above-average disadvantage and negative values mean below-average flood disadvantage. The value of -999 code means that the data zone is not exposed to a given type of flooding. These values are also provided as <string> categories according to a classification scheme. 5. Geographical location. The rurality of each data zone according to the Scottish Urban-Rural Classification (Scottish Government, 2014) is provided. A classification of the coastal and inland areas, is also provided based on the location of the data zone population-weighted centroid, and using three distance bands from the coast: 1 km, 2km and 10km.
A detailed methodology document is available. Please contact the data owners if this is not supplied with your dataset.
